Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Customer Discovery Activity for Microelectromechanical Systems based Gas Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is: it presents a market ready gas sensor system to monitor hazardous and industrial gas leakages such as chlorine and ammonia. Although detection of industrial gases is critical from technical, safety and environmental perspectives, there is a need for a straightforward technology to detect such industrial gas leakages on site. This team's portable gas sensor system will potentially satisfy this need. If successful, the proposed sensor system has potential applications in diverse fields such as: bleaching industries involving food, clothes and papers, agriculture, defense, and others.

This I-Corps project focuses on a micro-sized gas sensor system to detect leakage of industrial gases. This sensor system consists of nanoscale metal-oxide layer which will be made using a nanocomposite of graphene and metal oxides. Such composites have attractive properties such as low resistance and high active surface-area, which are important to enhance the performance of gas sensors. Also, this composite layer can be optimized for fast sensor response and enhanced selectivity for a particular gas. The low resistance of a sensor layer will allow designing of low impedance peripheral circuits while high active surface-area will allow fast response and improved selectivity of sensors. The sensors can be designed to reduce power consumption by reducing operation temperatures with integration of micromachined resistive heaters and catalyst layers. The sensor properties can be optimized for different gases at ambient conditions. The ability to integrate signal transfer by wireless technique will also be investigated for this sensor system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to conduct  Customer Discovery Activity for Microelectromechanical Systems based Gas Sensors deveoped in PI's research group. 

Project Outcomes:

  1. We have participated I-corps training program held in New Jersey. Our team prepared a business plan following the instructions provided by I-Corps teaching team. The presentations were conducted to the I-corps teaching team and other audiences. We obtained comments and criticisms from I-corps teaching team. Every steps were taken to follow their guidelines by carefully analyzing the comments. I (PI), student (Leader) and mentor were actively involved in this process. In particular, PI and leader have obtained lots of key experience in developing a business plan after this course.
  2. We have outreached to various customers (potential) related to gas sensor market. These people include, industries, educators, researchers, product development teams, commercialization teams, venture capitalists, sales managers, national lab researchers, policy makers and policy executors. Total of 104 people were interviewed during this period. These interviews were recorded and entered into I-corps website by our team members. These interviews were very useful to understand the usefulness of our research.
  3. We developed a business plan according to comments and criticisms obtained from customer interviews. It clearly indicated that micro machined gas sensors would have a greater commercialization potential related to workplace safety, environmental monitoring and manufacturing/industrial engineering.
  4. Data were analysed to meet future commercilization plan. Also, a sensor designing was conducted to show to the customers.
